channel.title: Go CDK
channel.copyright: Copyright © 2018–2019 The Go Cloud Development Kit Authors

item.title: Structuring Portable Code
item.description: The Go CDK’s APIs are intentionally structured to make it easier to separate your application’s core logic from the details of the services it is using.

item.title: Publish Messages to a Topic
item.description:
Publishing a message to a topic with the Go CDK takes two steps:

  1. Open a topic with the Pub/Sub provider of your choice (once per topic).
  2. Send messages on the topic.

item.title: Tutorial: Command-Line Uploader
item.description: This quickstart will build a command line application called upload that uploads files to blob storage on GCP, AWS, and Azure. Blob storage stores binary data under a string key, and is one of the most frequently used cloud services.

item.title: Tutorial: Guestbook Application
item.description: In this tutorial, we will deploy an existing Go CDK application called Guestbook locally, then on Google Cloud Platform (GCP), Amazon Web Services (AWS), and Azure.

item.title: URLs
item.description: In addition to creating portable types via provider-specific constructors (e.g., creating a *blob.Bucket using s3blob.OpenBucket), many portable types can also be created using a URL. The scheme of the URL specifies the provider, and each provider implementation has code to convert the URL into the data needed to call its constructor. For example, calling blob.OpenBucket("s3blob://my-bucket") will return a *blob.Bucket created using s3blob.OpenBucket.

item.title: Subscribe to Messages from a Topic
item.description:
Subscribing to receive message from a topic with the Go CDK takes three steps:

  1. Open a subscription to a topic with the Pub/Sub service of your choice (once per subscription).
  2. Receive and acknowledge messages from the topic. After completing any work related to the message, use the Ack method to prevent it from being redelivered.

item.title: Using provider-specific APIs
item.description: It is not feasible or desirable for APIs like blob.Bucket to encompass the full functionality of every provider. Rather, we intend to provide a subset of the most commonly used functionality. There will be cases where a developer wants to access provider-specific functionality, such as unexposed APIs or data fields, errors, or options. This can be accomplished using As functions.

item.title: Order Processor
item.description: In this tutorial, we will run a Go CDK application called Order Processor on a local machine.
